Curriculum Vitae, September 2015
206 W. Franklin St., CB# 8120
Chapel Hill, NC 27516-2524
jdavis36@live.unc.edu
Center
Jacob K. Javits Dissertation Fellowship
Visiting Scholar, University of California, Berkeley, Department of Demography
Post Doctoral Fellow, University of California, Santa Barbara, Department of Geography
Residential Fellow, University of California, Santa Barbara, Institute for Social,
Behavioral and Economic Research (ISBER)
Ph.D., Geography, University of California, Santa Barbara
Dissertation: “International Migration, Remittances, Fertility, and Development: Quantitative
and Qualitative Evidence from Central America”
Advisor: David Lopez-Carr
Research Interests: International Migration/Remittances, Child Well-Being/Education, Fertility/Population,
Environmental Change, Development/Poverty, Latin America, and Advanced Statistical
Methods.
EDUCATION
2012-present Postdoctoral Scholar, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, Carolina Population

PUBLICATIONS
Davis. J. (accepted). ¿Educación o Desintegración? The Ramifications of Parental Migration and
Remittances on Children’s Education in Western Guatemala. Journal of Latin American Studies.
Davis, J., R. Bilsborrow and C. Gray. (2015). Fertility Transition in the Ecuadorian Amazon: Progress and
Barriers for Indigenous Women. International Perspectives on Sexual and Reproductive Health 41(1): 1-10.
Davis, J. and D. Lopez-Carr. (2014). Migration, Remittances and Smallholder Decision-Making:
Implications for Land Use and Livelihood Change in Central America. Land Use Policy 36: 319-329.
Story of Peasant Isolation, Exploitation, and Coercion. Migration and Development 2(1): 132-149.

American Migrant-sending Households. International Migration Review 45(2): 325-347.

Development Studies 4(3-4): 117-132.
Davis, J. (2007). Remittances and Agricultural Change in Central America and the Caribbean. Global

Migration: The Case of Educational Attainment in Guatemalan Migrant-Sending Households.

South-to-South and domestic) on union dissolution in Nicaragua.
INVITED LECTURES
“Economic Migration and Indicators of Environmental Change: Quantitative and
Qualitative Evidence from Central America.” Curriculum for the Environment and Ecology,
University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. March.
“International Economic Migration and Left-Behind Children’s Educational Outcomes:
Qualitative and Quantitative Evidence from Guatemala.” Minnesota Population Center,
University of Minnesota. November.
“Migration and Remittance Effects on Children’s Well-being and Environmental Change.”
Department of Geography. University of Utah. November.
“International Migration, Remittances, Fertility, and Development: Quantitative Evidence
from Central America.” Department of Geography Colloquium, U.C. Santa Barbara. April.
“Land Use and Fertility Change in Central America.” Guest Lecturer in Geography 5
(Human Geography), U.C. Santa Barbara, April.
“Human Migration.” Guest Lecturer in Geography 141(Population Geography), U.C. Santa
Barbara, March.
“Latin American International Migration.” Guest Lecturer in Geography 155/255 (Latin
American Geography), U.C. Santa Barbara, March.
“The Effect of Remittances on Fertility and Resource Consumption in Guatemala.”
Department of Geography Colloquium, U.C. Santa Barbara. October.
“Plant and Animal Dispersal.” Guest Lecturer in Geography 167 (Biogeography), U.C. Santa
Barbara. February.
“The Effect of Forest Conversion Histories on Southern Appalachian Plethodontid
Salamanders.” Duke University’s Nicholas School of the Environment Master’s
Symposium, Durham, NC. April.
CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS AND POSTERS
“Decoupling Parental Absences from Remittances in Economic Migration: The Case of
Educational Attainment in Guatemala.” Population Association of America Annual Meeting,
San Diego, CA. April 29-May 1.
“Contrasting Migration Effects with Remittance Effects on Child Growth Outcomes in
Nicaragua.” Population Association of America Annual Meeting, San Diego, CA. April 29-
May 1. (poster)
“International and Domestic Economic Migration and Children’s Growth Outcomes in
Guatemala.” Population Association of America Annual Meeting, Boston, MA. May 1-3.
“Migration, Remittances and Smallholder Decision-Making: Implications for Land Use and
Livelihood Change in Central America.” Population Association of America Annual
Meeting, Boston, MA. May 1-3. (poster)
“Fertility Transition in the Ecuadorian Amazon: Progress and Barriers for Indigenous
Women.” Association of American Geographers Annual Meeting, Tampa, FL. April 8-12.
“Migration, Remittances and the Well-Being of Left-Behind Children: A National-level
Quantitative Assessment of Guatemala.” Population Association of America Annual
Meeting, New Orleans, LA. April 11-13. (poster)
“Ecuadorian Amazon Indigenous Fertility Dynamics Revisited: Why Sizable Contraceptive
Uptake has not Dampened High Fertility.” Population Association of America Annual
Meeting, New Orleans, LA. April 11-13. (poster)
“Migration, Remittances and the Well-Being of Left-Behind Guatemalan Children.” UC
Global Health Day, Berkeley, CA. February 4. (poster)
“Migration, Remittances and the Well-Being of Left-Behind Children: a National-Level
Quantitative Assessment of Guatemala.” 6th Summer Institute on Migration and Global
Health, University of California Global Health Institute, Berkeley, CA. June 20-24.
“The Effects of Migrant Remittances on Population-Environment Dynamics.” Association
of American Geographers Annual Meeting, Seattle, WA. April 12-16.
“The Effects of Migrant Remittances on Population-Environment Dynamics in Migrant
Origin Areas: International Migration, Fertility and Consumption in Highland Guatemala.”
Population Association of America Annual Meeting, Washington, D.C. March 31-April 2.
“Migration, Remittances and Cattle: Implications for Land Use Change and Food Security in
Central America.” Global Land Project Open Science Meeting, Phoenix, AZ. October 17-19.
“Effects of Migrant Remittances on Consumption in Highland Guatemala.” Proceedings of
the European Population Conference, Vienna, Austria. September 1-4.
“¿Educación o Desintegración? The Ramifications of Parental Migration and Remittances on
Children’s Education in Western Guatemala.” Population Association of America Annual
Meeting, Dallas, TX. April 15-17.
“Decoupling Migration Effects from Income Effects on Reproduction in Central American
Migrant-sending Households.” International Union for the Scientific Study of Population
International Population Conference, Marrakech, Morocco. September 27 – October 2.
“The Ecological Dimensions of Population Growth, Migration, and Urbanization.” Ecological
Society of America Annual Meeting. Albuquerque, New Mexico. August 6. (Authors: De
Sherbinin, A, S.B. Adamo, S.R. Baptista, J. Bremner, J. Davis, D.L. Carr, S.R. Curran, P.J.
Marcotullio.)
“Flowing Wealth, Circulating Labor and Reproduction in Central American Households.”
Population Association of America Annual Meeting, Detroit, MI. April 30-May 2.
“Motivations and Outcomes of Temporary Western Guatemalan Migration to the United
States.” Association of American Geographers Annual Meeting, Las Vegas, NV. March 22-27.
“How Does Migration to the U.S. and the Resultant Remittances Influence Fertility in
Migrant-sending Central American Households?” Conference of Latin Americanist
Geographers, Granada, Nicaragua. January 7-9.
“Flowing Wealth, Circulating Labor and Reproduction in Central American and
Caribbean Households.” Association of American Geographers Annual Meeting,
Boston, MA. April 15-19.
Discussant, “Consequences of Out-Migration for Rural Origin Areas.” Association of
American Geographers Annual Meeting, Boston, MA. April 15-19.
PROFESSIONAL SERVICE
“Population and Land Cover Change in Guatemala.” Annual Meeting of the Association of

Grace, J. Davis)
“The Effect of Remittances on Fertility, Conspicuous Consumption, and Agricultural
Change.” Association of American Geographers Annual Meeting, San Francisco, CA. April
“The Dynamic Interplay among International Migration, Remittances, Fertility, and
Resource Consumption in Rural Guatemala.” Association of American Geographers
Annual Meeting, Chicago, IL. March 7-11.
